repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab education reform
            increases access

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about Punjab
            education reform increased access in Pakistan. Punjab is
            Pakistan’s largest province with a population of 100
            million, which embodies 60 percent of the country's
            total population. In the country’s efforts to alleviate
            poverty, low educational attainment had long been a
            stumbling block. The International Development Association
            financed Punjab Education Sector Reform Program was launched
            in 2003 with the objective of improving access, quality, and
            governance in the education sector. A number of reforms in
            teachers’ recruitment and professional development, textbook
            production, and the examination system were implemented. As
            a result, net enrollment in primary schools in Punjab has
            increased from 45 to 62 percent between 2001 and 2007.
            Female primary net enrollment during the same period
            increased from 43 to 59 percent and for rural females from
            38 to 55 percent. The Punjab government has launched a
            second generation of reforms that focuses on increasing
            access and completion rates, enhancing the quality of
            reforms and student learning outcomes, and strengthening
            school management and sector governance.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab Education Reform
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Punjab Education Sector
            Development Policy Credit Project for Pakistan were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: Strong political support and government
            ownership is essential for any program to succeed. This
            leads to high level of monitoring and oversight. Continuity
            of the same team over a project, including officials and
            politicians at various tiers helps maintain momentum of
            reforms and enhances the probability of success of a
            program. Success of a program requires a flexible approach
            to implementation with effective monitoring and evaluation
            of the program during the implementation process with the
            help of relevant data and information to identify
            shortcomings and problem issues and be able to rectify them
            during the course of implementation. Strong ongoing
            analytical work helps deepen and refine policies and
            programs. Finally, the success of any education system is
            judged by the quality of its graduates. While quality
            remains the core desired outcome of any education reform
            program, it takes several years to show tangible results.
            Therefore, education reforms require a long term commitment,
            backed by a clear strategy for improving school level
            performance through both quantitative and qualitative inputs.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Education Sector
            Development Policy Credit - Punjab Province - Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the wide-range reform agenda of
            the Government of Pakistan, the Second Education Sector
            Development Policy Credit Project - Punjab Province - key
            pillars will support: a) public finance reforms to increase
            public spending for education (and other pro-poor services)
            and to ensure fiscal sustainability; b) reforms that
            strengthen devolution and improve the fiduciary environment
            and governance; and, c) education sector reforms to improve
            quality, access and sector governance. The main benefits
            will be reversing the slide in education indicators,
            bringing more children into school up to grade 8
            (particularly poor children and girls) sooner than
            previously expected, providing better quality education. The
            program would contribute to closing the social gap and
            helping the Country progress toward the Millennium
            Development Goals (MDGs) related to poverty reduction and
            Education for All (EFA). Another indirect, but important,
            benefit is that the program is strengthening
            decentralization by increasing the role of districts, and
            promoting accountability between service users (parents and
            students) and service providers (schools and teachers).
            Overall, given the success of the first year program, the
            risk rating is moderate for the second year program,
            proposed to be supported under this project. Nevertheless,
            there is a need to maintain continued vigilance in case of a
            change of priorities and focus at the political level, both
            at the province and districts.
